posts.name: Peter
posts.cooked:
Hello! Our code team is in need of some assistance.

So for our robot arm we would like to use the Rev through bore encoder so we can move our robot to a position by the push of a button. The arm is controlled by a Neo motor and a SparkMax. This goes into a 175:1 gear ratio. With this in mind, how could we use the Rev Through bore encoder to automatically rotate the arm to a given position

So for our robot arm we would like to use the Rev through bore encoder so we can move our robot to a position by the push of a button. The arm is controlled by a Neo motor and a SparkMax. This goes into a 175:1 gear ratio. With this in mind, how could we use the Rev Through bore encoder to automatically rotate the arm to a given position

Once the arm is in that position, how can we automatically engage the brake mode so the arm is kept at that position?

Once the arm is in that position, how can we automatically engage the brake mode so the arm is kept at that position?

If there’s any clarification I can provide, I’ll try. I am not on the code team so I’m not the most knowledgeable, but I will do my best.

posts.name: Ibrahim
posts.cooked:
In order to get your arm to a certain position using the through bore encoder you would have to use some kind of feedback loop like PID and tune it to achieve a certain angle, there is an amazing write-up on the wpilib docs about controlling an arm.

If you’re just trying to use brake mode, you can just set it to be brake mode and it will be at all times that it is not on coast mode, but brake mode is only used when it is not running but always enabled. In order to keep the arm at that position though, you would probably also want to use the help of a feedforward loop to counteract gravity. Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

link_counts.title: Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
These examples may help with (1):

In this section, we will tune a simple position controller for a vertical arm. The same tuning principles explained below will work also for almost all position-control scenarios under the load of ...

master/Java/Position%20Closed%20Loop%20Control

Example code for SPARK MAX. Contribute to REVrobotics/SPARK-MAX-Examples development by creating an account on GitHub.

For (2), you should be able to just configure your Spark Max controllers to be in brake mode all the time, no need to change it to coast for a mechanism like this. It might not be enough to hold the arm in place, depending on how heavy the arm is.

link_counts.title: SPARK-MAX-Examples/Java/Position Closed Loop Control at master · REVrobotics/SPARK-MAX-Examples · GitHub
Tuning a Vertical Arm Position Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Stephen Kalogiannis
posts.cooked: it likely wont hold the arm you will need a feed forward, are you planning on using the through bore as an absolute or incremental encoder?

posts.name: Peter
posts.cooked:
Our idea was absolute. And the weight of our arm should be low enough that it’s able to be held via brake mode.

If it isn’t how would we do the forward feed?

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked: Check out ReCalc - Arm Calculator for finding ArmFeedforward values.

posts.name: Peter
posts.cooked: This is what I got Where are the ArmFeedForward values?

posts.name: Weaver Goldman
posts.cooked: They are the kg kv and ka values at the bottom. You can put those in an arm feedforward from wpilib.

posts.name: slickvic2252
posts.cooked: What exactly is the difference between KG, KV, and KA?
